awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Cyber-Physical Sensing, Modeling, and Control for Large-Scale Wastewater Reuse and Algal Biomass Production
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops advanced cyber-physical sensing, modeling, control, and optimization methods to significantly improve the efficiency of algal biomass production using membrane bioreactor technologies for waste water processing and algal biofuel. Currently, many wastewater treatment plants are discharging treated wastewater containing significant amounts of nutrients, such as nitrogen, ammonium, and phosphate ions, directly into the water system, posing significant threats to the environment.  Large-scale algae production represents one of the most promising and attractive solutions for simultaneous wastewater treatment and biofuel production. The critical bottleneck is low algae productivity and high biofuel production cost.

The previous work of this research team has successfully developed an algae membrane bioreactor (A-MBR) technology for high-density algae production which doubles the productivity in an indoor bench-scale environment. The goal of this project is to explore advanced cyber-physical sensing, modeling, control, and optimization methods and co-design of the A-MBR system to bring the new algae production technology into the field. The specific goal is to increase the algal biomass productivity in current practice by three times in the field environment while minimizing land, capital, and operating costs. Specifically, the project will (1) adapt the A-MBR design to address unique new challenges for algae cultivation in field environments, (2) develop a multi-modality sensor network for real-time in-situ monitoring of key environmental variables for algae growth, (3) develop data-driven knowledge-based kinetic models for algae growth and automated methods for model calibration and verification using the real-time sensor network data, and (4) deploy the proposed CPS system and technologies in the field for performance evaluations and demonstrate its potentials.

This project will demonstrate a new pathway toward green and sustainable algae cultivation and biofuel production using wastewater, addressing two important challenging issues faced by our nation and the world: wastewater treatment and renewable energy. It will provide unique and exciting opportunities for mentoring graduate students with interdisciplinary training opportunities, involving K-12 students, women and minority students. With web-based access and control, this project will convert the bench-scale and pilot scale algae cultivation systems into an exciting interactive online learning platform to educate undergraduate and high-school students about cyber-physical system design, process control, and renewable biofuel production.

Publications:

2. Heng Qiao and Piya Pal, "Gridless Line Spectrum Estimation and Low-Rank Toeplitz Matrix Compression Using Structured Samplers: A Regularization-Free Approach", IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SIGNAL PROCESSING, VOL. 65, NO. 9, MAY 1, 2017.

 

3. Heng Qiao and Piya Pal, "Stable Compressive Low Rank Toeplitz Covariance Estimation Without Regularization", Proceedings of the 50th Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems and Computers (Asilomar 2016), pp. 384-388, Nov. 2016.

 

4. Heng Qiao and Piya Pal, "Unified Analysis of Co-Array Interpolation for Direction-of-Arrival Estimation",  Proceedings of 2017 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP), pp. 3056-3060, March 2017. [Winner of Best Student Paper Award, First Position]

 

5. Heng Qiao and Piya Pal, "Understanding the Role of Positive Constraints in Sparse Bilinear Problems",  Proceedings of  IEEE CAMSAP 2017.

 

6. Heng Qiao, Mehmet Can Hucumenoglu, Piya Pal, "Compressive Kriging Using Multi-Dimensional Generalized Nested Sampling", Proceedings of Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems and Computers, Nov, 2018.

 

7.  Piya Pal, "Correlation-Awareness in Low-Rank Models: Sampling, Algorithms and Fundamental Limits",  IEEE Signal Processing Magazine. vol. 35, no. 4, pp. 56-71, July 2018.

 

8. Heng Qiao. Structured Sub-Nyquist Sampling with Applications in Compressive Toeplitz Covariance Estimation, Super-Resolution and Phase Retrieval. (2019).  Ph.D Thesis, University of California, San Diego.

 

The overall objective of this interdisciplinary project is to investigate how advanced cyberphysical sensing, modeling, and control methods could be coupled with new design of algal membrane bioreactor to achieve highly efficient algae biomass production. To meet this overall goal, the specific objective of this project is to develop new energy efficient sensing and subsampling technologies for stable interpolation of a space-time series (capturing key environmental parameters such as temperature, oxygen content and so forth) from limited number of samples. In order to minimize the number of active sensors (and save computational and energy resources) for monitoring the environmental parameters associated with algal biomass production, we proposed a novel sampling geometry (that can be used to sub-select the requisite number of active sensors) namely, the Generalized Nested Sampler (GNS).

Our research findings have produced several fundamental results regarding sampling and stable interpolation of spatially wide sense stationary processes. For the first time, we have developed optimal sampling strategies for compressing low rank Toeplitz structured covariance matrices by modifying our proposed GNS samplers. These samplers provably outperform random sampling techniques, in terms of the number of measurements required for perfect reconstruction. Apart from the mathematical appeal, the result is highly significant for our project since we assume the covariance matrix of the sensor network to be spatially stationary, which imposes a Toeplitz structure. The GNS geometry shows how to select the optimum number of sensors (or samples) and reconstruct the correlation values at the missing (or unsampled) locations, which can ultimately be used for monitoring environmental parameters. On the algorithmic front, we have developed new regularization-free methods for low rank covariance estimation (based on projections onto appropriate convex sets), which avoids the need to tune parameters which often requires  knowledge of noise level.

Based on the theoretical concepts behind our regularizer free framework, we also developed a unified framework for analyzing the performance of any algorithm that aims to predict missing correlation lags from partially observed entries. Our results show the importance of certain positivity constraints (implied by the PSD structure of the estimated covariance matrix). Using this framework, we can now analyze the performance of any Toeplitz covariance prediction algorithm, and also obtain specific error bounds catered to specific algorithms.

 

Our theory and algorithms have broader applicability beyond this specific project. Many problems in signal processing and statistics involve Toeplitz structured covariance matrices, where the matrix plays the role of a sufficient statistic for statistical inference. Examples include source localization in radar and sonar, astronomical imaging, and compressive spectrum estimation for next generation wireless systems. The sampling techniques and reconstruction algorithms developed as part of this project can offer significant theoretical insights and enhance the performance of these algorithms.

 

The project resulted in several publications in peer reviewed conferences and journals. It also partially supported one graduate student who defended his Ph.D (in 2019) and is currently a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor-Shanghai Jiao Tong University Joint Institute. He also received the prestigious 2018 Shannon Graduate Fellowship from UC San Diego.
